question_title: STEPS TO REVIVE DYING TRADITIONAL WEAVING ART .
question_description: he efforts made by Government to revive the dying traditional weaving art for textiles across the country?
answer: THE MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF TEXTILES (SMT. PANABAAKA LAKSHMI) Sir, the Government of India is determined and committed for the revival of the dying traditional weaving art for the textiles across the country. For revival of the handloom industry and to popularize the products in the national and international market following steps are taken by the Government of India: (a) Registration of Handloom items under the Geographical Indications of Goods (Registration & Protection) Act, 1999. The Geographical Indications of Goods (Registration & Protection) Act, 1999 provides legal protection to only such authorized users who have exclusive rights to produce the goods in respect of which it has been registered. Under this Act, measures are taken for protection of traditional handloom items e.g. Banarasi brocade, Jamdani of Bengal etc. It is proposed to cover about 110 traditional handloom products of various States during the XI Plan period @ Rs.1.50 lakh per product. So far following handloom items have been registered under the GI Act:- Chanderi Sarees (Madhya Pradesh) and Pochampally Sarees (Andhra Pradesh), Kotpad Handloom fabric, Kota Doria (Rajasthan), Solapur chaddar, Solapur Terry towel (Maharashtra); have already been registered under the said Act. Narayanpet, Siddipet Gollabama, Mangalagiri and Venkatagiri Sarees of Andhra Pradesh; Sambalpuri Tie & Dye, Nuapatna Tie & Dye, Habaspuri Design, Bomkai Desing, Posapally design, Khandua Nuapatna, Berhampur Kumbha Sarees (silk), Dhalapathar Temple Design fabrics of Orissa; Santipuri, Tangail, Tangail Jamdani, Dhaniakhali, Baluchari, Korial, Garad Saree and Muslin of West Bengal; Silk Patola Sarees- single Ikat and Woollen acrylic shawl- Kutch/Masharoo of Gujarat; Guledgud Khana, Udupi Saree of Karnataka; Banarasi Saree and Banarasi Brocades of Uttar Pradesh; Maheshwari handloom items of Madhya Pradesh; Kasargod, Kuthampully, Chendamangalam, Balaramapuram sarees and Kannur handloom furnishings of Kerala; Wangkhei Phee, Safi Lanphee/ Sami Lamphee, Moirang Phee of Manipur State. In addition to the above Tamilnadu State registered Kancheepuram silk saree, Bhavani Jamukalam, Madurai Sungudi Sarees and action to register (1) Kovai cotton sarees (2) Salem Silk and (3) Arani Silk sarees of Tamilnadu is under process. (b) Promotion of use of HANDLOOM MARK: The Handloom sector faces many challenges and with the technological developments, the handloom products are being increasingly replicated on powerlooms at a much lower cost. While the Governmentâ<U+0080><U+0099>s endeavor is to create conditions for the harmonious growth of the entire textile industry, at the same time it would also like to ensure that there is well defined and delineated areas for handlooms which is not unduly encroached by the powerlooms and mills. Hence, the â<U+0080><U+009C>Handloom Markâ<U+0080> has been introduced to provide a collective identity to the handloom products which serves as a guarantee for the buyer that the product being purchased is genuinely hand woven and provides a distinct identity to the handloom products, both in India and abroad. The Handloom Mark has been registered under the Trade Marks Act, 1999 as well as for Copyright under the Copyright Act, 1957. 7420 Individual weavers, master weavers, handloom cooperative societies, handloom corporations, retailers and exporters, Self Help Groups, Joint Liability Groups, Consortia, Producer Company, Handloom Weavers Groups or any other legal entity, organization involved in Handloom activities and approved by the Development Commissioner for Handlooms are using the Handloom Mark labels with a one time registration fee. 745 retail outlets are selling the products with Handloom Mark label and 175.73 lakh handloom mark labels have been sold since 2006. (c) Implementation of the Handloom (Reservation of Articles for Production) Act, 1985: With a view to protect the interests and livelihood of the handloom weavers in the country, the Government of India promulgated the Handlooms (Reservation of Articles for Production) Act, 1985, dated29.3.1985. Under the Act, protection to the handlooms sector was extended by way of reserving certain textile articles for exclusive production by handlooms. On the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, 11 articles were reserved exclusive production by handlooms vide Notification No. 2160(E) dated 3.9.2008. The items reserved are: i. Saree; ii. Dhoti; iii. Towel, Gamcha and Angavastram; iv. Lungi; v. Khes, Bedsheet, Bedcover, Counterpane, Furnishing (Incl. tapestry, upholstery); vi. Jamakkalam Durry or Durret; vii. Dress Material; viii. Barrack Blankets, Kambal or Kamblies; ix. Shawls, Loi, Muffler, Pankhi etc.; x. Woollen Tweed; xi. Chadar, Mekhala/Phanek. The Office of the Development Commissioner for Handlooms implements the Act; Weavers Service Centres and Offices of the State Directors in charge of Handlooms implement the Act. During the XI Plan period upto October, 2010, 8,37,151 powerloom inspections have been conducted. (d ) Sant Kabeer Awards: In order to give accreditation to the talented weavers and craft persons, the Government of India has introduced Sant Kabeer Awards w.e.f. the year 2009, under which one mounted gold coin, one shawl and a citation is given to each Awardee, which may number up to 10 in a year. In addition, financial assistance to the extent of Rs.6.00 lakh will also be given to each of the Sant Kabeer Awardee to innovate and create 10 new products of high level of excellence of high aesthetic value and high quality. (e) Organising Design Exhibitions-cum-Dyeing Workshops: The Weavers Service Centres of this office organise Design Exhibitions-cum-Dyeing Workshops so as to educate the weavers and allied workers to improve their skills and to meet the market challenges by way of weaving new designs with different colour combinations. During the XI Plan up to October, 2010, 741 Design Exhibitions-cum-Dyeing Workshops have been organized. (f) Providing new designs through National Centre for Textile Design: The National Centre for Textile Design provides ethnic and contemporary designs developed by the Weaversâ<U+0080><U+0099> Service Centres to the textile sector through the web portal www.designdiary.nic.in through the design pool available in 12 Indian regional languages, including Tamil. There are 1081 designs available on the website which are downloadable free of cost. More than one lakh viewers have visited this site. (g) Apart from the above, to protect the handloom weavers and their traditional art, the Government of India is implementing following Schemes for the development of handloom sector and welfare of weavers: Integrated Handlooms Development Scheme This scheme provides need based inputs to develop â<U+0080><U+009C>Clustersâ<U+0080> of 300-500 Handloom or â<U+0080><U+009C>Groupsâ<U+0080> of 10-100 weavers for making them self-sustainable by providing them financial assistance for margin money, working capital, new looms and accessories, skill-upgradation training in weaving, dyeing and processing, designing, marketing opportunities and for providing assistance for construction of workshed, Handloom Weaversâ<U+0080><U+0099> Comprehensive Welfare Scheme This comprises of two separate schemes viz. the Health Insurance Scheme (HIS) for providing Health Insurance to the Handloom weavers and Mahatma Gandhi Bunkar Bima Yojana (MGBBY) for providing Life Insurance Cover in case of natural/ accidental death, total/partial disability due to accident. Marketing & Export Promotion Scheme This scheme provides marketing opportunities and infrastructure support through design development and marketing linkages to assist in the sale of the Handloom products both in domestic and international market. Mill Gate Price Scheme This scheme makes available all types of yarn at Mill Gate Price to the eligible handloom agencies to facilitate regular supply of basic raw material to the handloom weavers and to optimize their employment potential. Diversified Handloom Development Scheme This scheme provides assistance for technological and skill up gradation of weavers for design and product development through 25 Weaversâ<U+0080><U+0099> Service Centres and 05 Indian Institutes of Handloom Technology all over the country to improve the productivity and earnings of the handloom weavers.

question_title: CHECKING SUPPLY OF WEAPONS TO EXTREMISTS FROM CHINA .
question_description: (a) whether Government is aware that the destructive weapons are supplied to the extremist organization called Nationalist Socialist Council of Nagaland, NSCN (IM) from China; (b) whether such weapons are also supplied to the Marxist Naxalite Organisations operating in India from China; (c) if so, the routes through which these weapons are supplied; and (d) the steps being taken to check supply of these deadly weapons to the extremist organizations operating in India?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI MULLAPPALLY RAMACHANDRAN) (a): There have been recent reports of nationalist Socialist Council of Nagaland (Isak/Muivah) (NSCN/IM) procuring arms from China. (b): Specific reports in this regard have not been received. (c): Inputs suggest that arms are procured by Indian Insurgent Groups (IIGs) operating in the North East, through arms smugglers based in South East Asia and in Yunnan Province of China through the Sino-Myanmar border and the porous Indo-Myanmar border. (d): The security forces along the border have been patrolling the border areas regularly and they have been suitably sensitized regarding arms smuggling by the insurgents from time to time. Government of India has voiced its concerns with the Governments of Myanmar and Bangladesh, over the reported smuggling of arms through their territories.

question_title: STUDENTS BENEFITED FROM SCHOLARSHIP SCHEMES .
question_description: (a) the community-wise breakup of students who took benefit of scholarship schemes of the minorities during the last three years; (b) whether the Ministry aims for proportionate distribution of scholarship to children of different communities, as per their ratio in population and if so, how it would be ensured; (c) the ratio of girl students benefited from such schemes; and (d) whether these schemes are also extended to minority community of Jammu and Kashmir, Punjab, Nagaland and Mizoram?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE), IN THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a): Minority community-wise details of beneficiaries benefited under the Pre-Matric, Post-Matric and Merit cum Means based scholarship schemes during the last three years are annexed. (b): The scholarships have been allocated equitably among the students of various minority communities, notified under section 2(c) of the National Commission for Minorities Act, 1992, throughout the country based on the State/UT-wise ratio of population of the minority communities based on 2001 census. (c): The percentage of girls benefited under these schemes during the last three years is annexed. (d): Benefits of these schemes are extended to the five religious communities namely, Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Buddhists and Zoroastrians(parsis) which have been declared as minority communities under section 2(c) of the National Commission for Minorities Act, 1992, regardless of the states in which they stay.

question_title: MEDICAL AND ENGINEERING COLLEGES IN NEW CENTRAL UNIVERSITIES .
question_description: (a) whether medical colleges and engineering colleges have normally been part of central universities in the country, and; (b) if so, whether the new central universities established and proposed to be established are going to have a medical and an engineering college?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT (SMT. D. PURANDESWARI) (a) The Central Universities are statutory autonomous bodies and some of these Universities, such as Aligarh Muslim University and Banaras Hindu University are having Medical and Engineering Colleges. (b) The 16 new Central Universities established under the Central Universities Act, 2009 are empowered to have a Medical and Engineering Colleges under their fold, subject to availability of resources.

question_title: MEASURES TO DISCOURAGE PEOPLE FROM USING TOBACCO
question_description: (a) whether a survey has been conducted by the Global Adult Tobacco Survey (GATS) regarding use of tobacco; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether it is a fact that some of the States/UTs namely, Punjab, Goa and Chandigarh, have the lowest tobacco user rate; (d) if so, the reasons therefor; (e) whether Government is planning to extend the measures for encouraging low use of tobacco to other States; (f) if not, the reasons therefor; and (g) the measures Government will take to deter people from using tobacco products?
answer: THE MINISTER OF HEALTH AND FAMILY WELFARE (SHRI GHULAM NABI AZAD) (a)to(g): A statement is laid on the Table of the House. STATEMENT REFERRED TO IN REPLY TO RAJYA SABHA STARRED QUESTION NO. 282 FOR 30TH NOVEMBER, 2010 ..... (a) Yes, Sir. (b) Global Adult Tobacco Survey (GATS) India, 2010, revealed that 35% of adults in India use tobacco in some form or the other. 21% adults use only smokeless tobacco, 9% use only smoking forms and 5% use smoking as well as smokeless tobacco. The estimated number of tobacco users in India is 274.9 million with 163. 7 million users of smokeless tobacco (chewing tobacco i.e khaini, gutkha, pan masala, etc.), 68.9 million are smokers and 42.3 million use both smoking and smokeless forms of tobacco. Prevalence of overall tobacco use is 48% among men and 20% among women. Other details regarding prevalence of tobacco users are available in GATS India Report. (c)&(d): Yes, Sir, it is a fact that some of the States have lower tobacco user rate e.g. Chandigarh (14%), Punjab (12%) and Goa (9%). Though GATS did not study the reasons for low prevalence of tobacco use, it is felt that this is due to socio-cultural and religious reasons. (e)to(g): Government of India has undertaken several steps for deterring people from using tobacco products. â<U+0080><U+009C>The Cigarette and Other Tobacco Products (Prohibition of Advertisement and Regulation of Trade and Commerce, Production, Supply and Distribution) Act, 2003 (COTPA)â<U+0080> has been enacted to protect citizens from second hand smoke and to discourage them from consumption of cigarettes and other tobacco products by imposing various regulatory measures. With effect from 2nd October, 2008, Government of India has imposed ban on smoking in public places. Similarly, ban on sale of tobacco products to minors (i.e. persons below 18 years) and ban on sale of tobacco products within 100 yards of educational institutions, have been imposed by the Government. In addition to this, Specified Health Warnings including Pictorial Health Warnings have been made mandatory to be depicted on all consumer packaging of tobacco products with effect from 31st May, 2009. Further, Government of India has also launched a National Tobacco Control Programme to create awareness on the hazards of Tobacco and to help States to implement tobacco Control Laws. ...

question_title: CAMPAIGNS AGAINST FEMALE FOETICIDES
question_description: (a) whether Government proposes to highlight the performance of women sportspersons in the recently concluded Commonwealth Games in its campaigns against female foeticides and save the girl child campaign; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether the help of religious leaders has also been sought to prevent female foeticides in the country; (d) if so, the details thereof; and (e) if not the reasons therefor?
answer: THE MINISTER OF HEALTH AND FAMILY WELFARE (SHRI GHULAM NABI AZAD) (a)&(b): Though at present there is no such proposal, the Government recognises the importance of projecting women achievers in the campaign against female foeticide. (c)to(e): Yes, Sir. Religious leaders are involved in awareness generation against female foeticide. .....

question_title: KILLING OF HINDI SPEAKING PEOPLE BY PRO BODOLAND GROUPS IN ASSAM .
question_description: (a) whether Government is aware that pro Bodoland groups had killed more than two dozen Hindi speaking poor labourers in Assam in November; (b) if so, the reasons therefor; (c) whether Government is taking some concrete steps to safeguard the life and property of Hindi speaking people,; (d) if so, the details thereof; (e) whether Government of Assam has provided financial assistance to victims` families; and (f) if not, the reasons therefor?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI MULLAPPALLY RAMACHANDRAN) (a) to (d): As per report, cadres of National Democratic Front of Boroland (Anti-Talk) (NDFB/AT) group killed 22 civilians belonging to Hindi speaking section, Bengalis, Assamese, Nepali, Bodo and Muslim communities and inflicted injuries to 15 persons in six Districts of Assam between 8-11 November 2010. Union Home Minister visited Assam on 12th November 2010 and had a meeting with the Chief Minister of Assam, senior officials of Government of Assam, Security Forces and intelligence agencies during which the security situation in the State was reviewed. State Government has been requested to strengthen security in the vulnerable areas including gearing up of intelligence agencies and chalking out an Operational Action Plan to deal with the situation. Besides, Government has taken various steps to check the militant activities in the North Eastern Region including Assam. These, inter alia, include deployment of Para-military Forces and Army in the State, coordinated counter insurgency operations by Army, Para Military Forces and State Police, declaration of insurgent groups as unlawful association under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967, reimbursement of security; related expenditure to the State Governments and modernization/up-gradation of State Police Force. Regular review of the Situation both at State and Central Government level is being made. (e): The matter of providing ex-gratia grant to the Next of kin of the victims is under process of the State Government. (f): In view of the (e) above does not arise.

question_title: REPORT OF ALL PARTY DELEGATION TO J K .
question_description: (a) the details of report of the all party delegation sent to Jammu & Kashmir by Government; (b) whether it is a fact that even muslim families have also started migrating from valley now; and (c) if so, the steps being taken by Government to bring peace into the valley?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI AJAY MAKEN) (a): Report of the All Party Delegation sent to Jammu & Kashmir indicated the measures to be taken to bring peace in Kashmir. Based on the same, the Government has approved an eight point plan. (b): No migration of Muslim families from valley has been reported by the Government of J&K. (c): The Central and State Government of J&K have taken following steps to bring peace into the valley:- (i). Government has appointed three Interlocutors to hold a sustained dialogue with all sections of the people in J&K. (ii). Two Special Task Forces, one each for Jammu region and Ladakh region, to examine the developmental needs of the two regions have also been appointed. (iii). State Government has been authorized for the payment of Rs.5 lakhs to the families of each of the deceased. (iv). Special Plan Assistance of Rs. 100.00 crore has been released to Government of J&K for grants to schools and colleges for improvements and addition to the existing infrastructure. (v). State Government has released 50 stone palters and 13 PSA detenues and 26 bunkers have been removed from various locations in Srinagar. This is an on-going process by the State Government.

question_title: RELATIONS WITH MYANMAR .
question_description: (a) the steps taken to strengthen the cultural relations with Myanmar; (b) the details of the usage of â<U+0080><U+0098>Mandle Jailâ<U+0080><U+0099> related to the memories of Lokmanya Tilak; and (c) the names of places and evolutionary methods related to Buddist tradition that have been tried to be used as a formula for unity?
answer: THE MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF EXTERNAL AFFAIRS (SMT. PRENEET KAUR) (a) India and Myanmar are close and friendly neighbours linked, inter-alia, by civilizational bonds, geographical proximity, culture, history and religion. During the visit of Senior General Than Shwe, Chairman of the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC) of the Union of Myanmar from 25th to 29th July 2010, both sides agreed to further strengthen and broaden the multi dimensional relationship, including in the area of culture. An MOU was also signed on conservation and restoration of Ananda Temple in Bagan, Myanmar. (b) Mandalay jail has been associated with the memories of Lokmanya Tilak. However, its current usage is not known. (c) Myanmar has a strong Buddhist tradition and they see India as the land of Buddha.

question_title: UNIVERSITIES UNDER CONSIDERATION FOR GRANT OF MINORITY STATUS .
question_description: (a) the number of universities in the country which have been granted minority status; and (b) whether any other university is under consideration of Government for grant of minority status?
answer: MINISTER OF HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT (SHRI KAPIL SIBAL) (a) & (b): A statement is laid on the table of the House. STATEMENT REFERRED TO IN REPLY TO PARTS (a) & (b) OF RAJYA SABHA STARRED QUESTION NO. 344 ASKED BY SHRI RAASHID ALVI, HON`BLE M.P. FOR 03.12.2010 REGARDING UNIVERSITIES UNDER CONSIDERATION FOR GRANT OF MINORITY STATUS. (a) The question as to whether an educational institution enjoys minority status under Article 30 (1) of the Constitution is determined by the provisions of the Act/Statutes/Memorandum of Association establishing that institution. The minority character of educational institutions, including universities, is recognized by the central/state government, under whose jurisdiction the institution falls. The National Commission for Minority Educational Institutions can also recognize the minority status of educational institution in matters coming under its purview. While information regarding recognition by States of the minority status of universities is not maintained centrally, among the Central Universities, Aligarh Muslim University (AMU), defined in its Act as â<U+0080><U+009C>the educational institution of their choice established by the Muslims of Indiaâ<U+0080>, has been so recognized by the Central Government. However, the matter is sub-judice before the Supreme Court of India. (b) The question of granting minority status to educational institutions established by legislatures being sub- judice in the matter of AMU, the Central Government is not considering any other matter at present.

question_title: BRT WILDLIFE SANCTUARY .
question_description: (a) whether the State Government of Karnataka has submitted a request for declaring Biligiri Rangaswamy Temple (BRT) Wildlife Sanctuary as a Tiger Reserve, since 2005; (b) whether additional information desired by the Central Government was furnished by the State Government in July, 2009; and (c) by when the Ministryâ<U+0080><U+0099>s approval in this regard is expected?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) FOR ENVIRONMENT AND FORESTS (SHRI JAIRAM RAMESH) (a), (b) & (c):- A statement is laid on the Table of the House. STATEMENT REFERRED TO IN REPLY TO PARTS (a), (b) & (c) OF RAJYA SABHA STARRED QUESTION NO. 272 ON BRT WILDLIFE SANCTUARY DUE FOR REPLY ON 29.11.2010. (a), (b) & (c) An earlier proposal received from the State (Karnataka) in this regard was not considered, since declaration of new tiger reserves was not viewed favourably in the 38th meeting of the Steering Committee of Project Tiger held on 12.4.2005. Subsequently, based on a communication received in December, 2008, the State was advised to send a revised proposal vis-Ã -vis the provisions of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972, besides the landscape / ecological parameters. On receipt of the same from the State, the â<U+0080><U+0098>in-principleâ<U+0080><U+0099> approval has been accorded on 20.9.2010 for constituting the Biligiri Ranganatha Swamy Temple Tiger Reserve. The State has been requested to send a detailed proposal in this regard, as required under section 38V of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972.

question_title: ENROLMENT OF MUSLIM GIRL CHILDREN IN SCHOOLS .
question_description: (a) the details of enrolment of Muslim girl children in primary and upper primary schools, State-wise; (b) whether it is a fact that the enrolment of Muslim girls in primary and upper primary schools had gone beyond the national average last year; (c) if so, the percentage of total Muslim girl children enrolled during the last year; and (d) the efforts the Ministry is making or proposes to make to enroll more and more Muslim girls, particularly poor, in primary and upper primary schools?
answer: MINISTER OF HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT (SHRI KAPIL SIBAL) (a) to (d) A statement is laid on the Table of the House. Statement referred to in reply to Rajya Sabha Starred Question No. 359 for answer on 3rd December, 2010 regarding â<U+0080><U+009C>Enrolment of Muslim girl children in schoolsâ<U+0080> asked by Shrimati Gundu Sudharani (a) A statement giving details of enrollment of Muslim girls in primary and upper primary schools, State-wise for 2008-09 is attached at Annexure. (b) & (c) The percentage of Muslim girls enrolled in 2008-09 as a percentage of total Muslim children was 48.97% at primary level compared with the national average of 48.40% girlâ<U+0080><U+0099>s enrollment. At the upper primary level the percentage of Muslim girls enrolled in 2008-09 as a percentage of total Muslim children was 50.09% compared with the national average of 47.57 % girlsâ<U+0080><U+0099> enrollment. (d) SSA interventions for opening new schools, providing additional teachers, constructing additional classrooms, providing textbooks and supplementary learning material, conducting teacher training and augmenting academic resource support, benefit all children, including Muslim children. In addition, SSA has opened Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalayas (KGBVs) at the upper primary level where 75% of seats are reserved for SC/ST/Muslim category girls. 427 KGBVs have been sanctioned in educationally backward blocks having over 20% Muslim population. Provision has also been made for a section to provide instruction in Urdu medium in KGBVs in minority blocks. SSA also provides school grant, teacher grant, free text books to all children in recognized Madarasas and Maktabs. Government is also implementing the Scheme for Promotion of Quality Education in Madarasas (SPQEM) to encourage traditional institutions like Madarasas and Maktabs to introduce modern subjects in their curriculum. In addition, the Government is implementing the scheme of Infrastructure Development in Minority Institutions (IDMI) to augment school infrastructure in Minority Institutions (elementary/ secondary/senior secondary schools) and expand facilities for formal education to children of minority communities. The scheme aim at inter alia encouraging education facilities for girls, children with special needs and those who are most deprived educationally amongst minorities.

question_title: SETTING UP OF NEW TIGER RESERVES .
question_description: (a) whether Government proposes to set up eight new tiger reserves in the country; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether locations for setting up of these reserves have been identified and if so, the details thereof; (d) the details of estimated expenditure likely to be incurred thereon; and (e) by when it is likely to be completed?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) FOR ENVIRONMENT AND FORESTS (SHRI JAIRAM RAMESH) (a), (b), (c), (d) & (e):- A statement is laid on the Table of the House. STATEMENT REFERRED TO IN REPLY TO PARTS (a), (b), (c), (d) & (e) OF RAJYA SABHA STARRED QUESTION NO. 365 ON SETTING UP OF NEW TIGER RESERVES DUE FOR REPLY ON 06.12.2010. (a), (b), (c), (d) & (e) The â<U+0080><U+009C>in-principleâ<U+0080> approval has been accorded by the National Tiger Conservation Authority for creation of four new tiger reserves, and the sites are: Biligiri Ranganatha Swamy Temple Sanctuary (Karnataka), Pilibhit (Uttar Pradesh), Ratapani (Madhya Pradesh) and Sunabeda (Orissa). question_title: IMPLEMENTATION OF RGNCS AND DHANALAKSHMI SCHEME. .
question_description: (a) the States which have implemented the Rajiv Gandhi National Creche Scheme (RGNCS) for the children of working mothers after signing the Memorandum of Understanding with the Central Government and the budget allocated to these States under the scheme during the current financial year; and (b) the details of the budget allocated to the States during the last three years under â<U+0080><U+009C>Dhanalakshmiâ<U+0080> a Scheme for Conditional Cash Transfer for the Girl Child started by the Central Government in March, 2008?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE OF THE MINISTRY OF WOMEN AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT (SHRIMATI KRISHNA TIRATH) (a) Rajiv Gandhi National Creche Scheme for the Children of Working Mothers is a Central Sector Scheme which envisages implementation through Central Social Welfare Board and two national level NGOs, namely, Indian Council for Child Welfare and Bhartiya Adim Jati Sevak Sangh. Funds are released to these implementing agencies. Thus, there is no State-wise allocation. There is no provision under the scheme for signing of Memorandum of Understanding with State Governments/UT Administrations. Rs. 70.00 crore. has been allocated for implementation of the scheme in 2010-11. (b) State-wise details of budget allocated for the last three years under the â<U+0080><U+009C>Dhanalakshmiâ<U+0080> scheme are annexed.

question_title: SOCIO ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT OF MUSLIM WOMEN
question_description: (a) whether it is a fact that Sachar Committee has expressed that socio-economic conditions of Muslim women is quite pathetic in the country ; and (b) if so, the details thereof and the reasons therefor?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) OF THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) and (b) : The salient findings of the Prime Ministerâ<U+0080><U+0099>s High Level Committee on Social, Economic and Educational Status of the Muslim Community of India (also known as Sachar Committee), which includes Muslim Women are annexed. The Sachar Committee had brought out clearly the educational deprivation experienced by the Muslim community and that the problem is more acute for girls/women. It had observed that low aggregate work participation ratios for Muslims are essentially due to much lower participation in economic activity by women in the community. The report mentions that â<U+0080><U+009C>one of the reasons for lower participation rates of Muslim women may be higher dependency rates due to relatively higher share of younger population in the community, resulting in women staying at home â<U+0080><U+009C>. Annex referred to in reply to parts (a) and (b) of Rajya Sabha Unstarred Question No.2877 asked by Shri RUDRA NARAYAN PANI and SHRI PRABHAT JHA on Socio-economic development of Muslim women to be answered on 06.12.2010 SALIENT FINDINGS OF THE SACHAR COMMITTEE (I) Education: (a) The literacy rate among Muslims was 59.1%, which was below the national average of 64.8 %. (b) The mean years of schooling (MYS) is lower compared to the average MYS for all children. (c) 25% of Muslim children in the 6 â<U+0080><U+0093> 14 year age group have either never attended school or have dropped out. (d) The majority of Muslim girls and boys fail in their matriculation examination or drop out before that. (e) Less than 4% of Muslims are graduates or diploma holders compared to about 7% of the population aged 20 years and above. (f) There is a strong desire and enthusiasm for education among Muslim women and girls across the board. (g) Schools beyond primary level are few in Muslim localities. Exclusive schools for girls are fewer. (h) Lack of hostel facilities is a limiting factor, especially for girls. (i) Muslim parents are not averse to modern or mainstream education and to sending their children to affordable Government schools. They do not necessarily prefer to send children to madarsas. However, the access to government schools for Muslim children is limited. (II) Skill development (a) Skill development initiatives for those who have not completed school education may be particularly relevant for some sections of Muslims given their occupational structure. (b) The skill demands in the manufacturing and service sectors are changing continuously and youth with middle school education would meet these needs. (c) A rehabilitation package for innovative re-skilling and for upgrading the occupational structure in the wake of liberalization is seen as an urgent need. (III) Employment and economic opportunities: (a) Self-employment is the main source of income of Muslims. They are engaged more in self-employed manufacturing and trade activities compared to others. (b) The share of Muslim workers engaged in street vending is the highest. More than 12 per cent of Muslim male workers are engaged in street vending as compared to the national average of less than 8 per cent. (c) The percentage of women Muslim workers undertaking work within their own homes is much larger at 70 per cent compared to all workers at 51 per cent. (d) The share of Muslims in the total workers engaged in the tobacco and textiles/garment related industries are quite significant. (e) The share of Muslim workers in production related activities and transport equipment operation is much higher at 34%, as against 21% of all workers. (f) More than 16 per cent of Muslims were engaged as sales workers, while the national average was only about 10 per cent. (g) While the participation of Muslim workers is relatively higher in production and sales related occupations, their participation was relatively lower in professional, technical, clerical and to some extent managerial work. (h) Muslims, by and large, are engaged in the unorganized sector of the economy and have to bear the brunt of liberalization. (i) The participation of Muslims in regular salaried jobs is much less than workers of other socio-religious categories. (j) Muslims are relatively more vulnerable in terms of conditions of work as their concentration in informal sector employment is higher and their job conditions, even among regular workers, are less for Muslims than those of other socio-religious communities. (k) Percentage of households availing banking facilities is much lower in villages where the share of Muslim population is high. (IV) Poverty and development (a) About 38 % of Muslims in urban areas and 27 % in rural areas live below the poverty level. (b) Muslims are concentrated in locations with poor infrastructure facilities. This affects their access to basic services like education, health facilities, transport, etc. (c) About a third of small villages with high concentration of Muslims do not have any educational institutions. (d) There is a scarcity of medical facilities in larger villages with a substantial Muslim concentration. About 40% of large villages with a substantial Muslim concentration do not have any medical facilities. (e) Muslim concentration villages are not well served with pucca roads. (f) Policies to deal with the relative deprivation of the Muslims in the country should sharply focus on inclusive development and mainstreaming of the community while respecting diversity. (v) Social conditions (a) A community-specific factor for low educational achievement is that Muslims do not see education as necessarily translating into formal employment (b) The Muslim population shows an increasingly better sex ratio compared with other socio-religious communities. (c) Infant and childhood mortality among Muslims is slightly lower than the average. (d) There has been a large decline in fertility in all the religious groups including Muslims.

question_title: RESEARCH WORK BY NCM
question_description: (a) whether it is a fact that a certain amount is reserved for research work in National Commission for Minorities; (b) whether it is also a fact that no worthwhile research is being undertaken in the Commission and the money allocated for the purpose is lapsing year after year; (c) if so, the reasons therefor; and (d) the action being taken to do the required research work?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE), IN THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) : Yes,Sir. (b),(c) and (d) : During the last three years, eight research studies, including two ongoing , concerning minorities have been undertaken by National Commission for Minorities. A statement showing the studies undertaken during the last three years is annexed. The entire budget provision was utilized in 2007-08 whereas Rs. 12.96 lakh and Rs 4.14 lakh could be utilized in 2008-2009 and 2009-10 respectively against budget provision of Rs. 18 lakh each in both the years. The amount had to be surrendered because of inadequate response to the Notice Inviting Tender. Annex STATEMENT REFERRED TO IN REPLY TO PARTS (B),(C) AND (D) OF THE RAJYA SABHA UNSTARRED QUESTION NO. 2878 ASKED BY SHRI MOHAMMED ADEEB TO BE ANSWERED ON 6.12.2010. STUDIES UNDERTAKEN DURING THE LAST THREE YEARS (2007-08, 2008-09 and 2009-10 ) (i) To monitor the coverage of issues and concerns of minorities on television. (ii) Study of socio-economic status of minorities other than Muslims. (iii) Dalits in the Muslim and Christian communities â<U+0080><U+0093> A status report on current social scientific knowledge. (iv) Study on social, economic, educational, cultural, traditional and occupational status of Sikligar, Lubana and Banjaras Sikhs. (v) Study on socio economic and educational status of the Parsi community in India. (vi) Study on Bhoti language. DURING THE CURRENT YEAR (2010-11) (i) Effects of recent recessions as well as liberalization of Indian economy on the workforce engaged in small, cottage and handicrafts work, particularly on Muslim minority of India and identification of areas of these effects as well as remedies thereof. (ii) Compilation of important legal texts and case laws on minority rights.

question_title: SOCIO ECONOMIC DIFFERENCE OF MINORITIES
question_description: (a) whether the Sachar Committee has taken into account differentials between States, especially between the north and south of the country, in the socio-economic and human development indices relating to the Muslim minority; (b) if not, whether the Ministry proposes to undertake such an evaluation, including those in the light of the information published recently by Prof. Iqbal Hasnain, former Vice-Chancellor of Calicut (Kozhikod(e) University; (c) whether the best practices in respect particularly of primary secondary and higher education for the minorities being promoted in one State region are being consciously promoted in other States regions; and (d) if so, the details thereof and if not, the reasons therefor?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) OF THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) and (b): The Sachar Committee has taken into account the socio-economic indicators of top 100 districts (by size of Muslim population) and religious differentials in some indicators of selected States. Government has already taken decisions on the follow up action on the recommendations of Sachar Committee and its implementation is monitored by the Government. (c) and (d): The Centrally Sponsored Schemes relating to primary, secondary and higher education for the minorities are implemented uniformly in all States / UTs in the country.

question_title: CRITERIA FOR FORMATION OF REGIMENT .
question_description: (a) what are the consideration and criteria for the formation/creation of a regiment; (b) whether there is any plan and proposal for the creation of a regiment to be designated as `Tribal Regiment`; (c) if so, the details thereof; and (d) if not, the reasons therefor?
answer: MINISTER OF DEFENCE (SHRI A.K. ANTONY) (a) to (d): Regiments are raised keeping in view national security scenario, threat assessment and operational necessity. There is no proposal to raise a `Tribal Regiment`. The policy of the Government is not to raise any new regiment on the basis of a particular class, creed, community, religion or region, but to have an Army in which all Indians have representation.

question_title: REACTIVATING TERRORIST ELEMENTS IN PUNJAB .
question_description: (a) whether Government is aware that inimical agencies abroad have been attempting to reactivate Sikh terrorist elements, forging a nexus between Lashkare- Taiba and terror groups like Babbar Khalsa International, Khalistan Zindabad Force and mobilizing their resources for planning terrorist violence in Punjab; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether it is also a fact that Khalistani groups have now set up a new base in Malaysia and sending arms to carry out terror strike in Punjab; (d) if so, the details thereof including the arms etc. recovered by Government during the last six months from suspected terrorists; and (e) what is Government`s reaction in regard thereto?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI AJAY MAKEN) (a) to (e): A Statement is laid on the Table of the House. STATEMENT IN REPLY TO PARTS (a) TO (e) OF THE RAJYA SABHA UNSTARRED QUESTION NO. 3162 FOR 08.12.2010. (a) & (b): Available reports suggest that Sikh Militant groups especially those based abroad, continue to persist with their efforts to revive militancy in Punjab. However, there are no specific inputs, at present, indicating nexus between Lashkar-e-Taiba and terror group like Babbar Khalsa International and Khalistan Zindabad Force. (c) to (e): The Indian security agencies are in constant contact with their counterparts in Malaysia through established mechanism of mutual cooperation in counter terrorism effort.

question_title: FRESH VISA GUIDELINES .
question_description: (a) whether it is a fact that Government has issued fresh visa guidelines allowing jobs for only highly skilled and salaried foreign national; (b) whether Government has received representations from the power companies to allow Chinese workers to continue working here for projects that are being installed by Chinese manufacturers; (c) how does Government plan to address this problem in the long term in cases where overseas companies are responsible for testing and evaluation of equipment; and (d) the number of under skilled workers who were present in India on the date of the said notification?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI MULLAPPALLY RAMACHANDRAN) (a): The guidelines on Employment Visa have been reviewed by the Government with a view to ensure that Employment Visa is granted only for highly skilled and/or qualified personnel. It has been decided that a foreign national being sponsored for an Employment Visa in any sector should draw a salary in excess of US$ 25,000 per annum. However, this condition of annual floor limit on income will not apply to : (a) Ethnic cooks, (b) Language teachers (other than English language teachers)/translators and (c) Staff working for the concerned Embassy/High Commission in India. (b) to (d): A separate visa regime, labelled as Project (â<U+0080><U+0098>Pâ<U+0080><U+0099>) visa within the Employment Visa chapter, has been introduced for foreign nationals coming to India for execution of projects in the power and steel sectors. In case of those who are already in the country and working on projects on Employment Visa can get extension on their Employment Visa subject to the fulfilment of the conditions. Foreign experts/ specialists on a visit of short duration in connection with an ongoing project with the objective of monitoring the progress of work, conducting meetings with Indian customers and/or to provide technical guidance can obtain a Business Visa from the Indian Missions/Posts abroad. Statistical data of unskilled workers in the country is not centrally maintained.

question_title: ATTEMPT TO FACILITATE SETTLEMENT OF AYODHYA ISSUE .
question_description: (a) what is the status of attempts made so far for out of court settlement of Babri Masjid-Ram Janam Bhumi dispute after the recent Allahabad High Court Judgment announced on 30 September, 2010; (b) whether Government has made any attempt to facilitate the settlement; and (c) if so, the details in this regard?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS (SHRI AJAY MAKEN) (a) to (c): The Central Government has not made any attempt for out of court settlement of Ram Janam Bhoomi-Babri Madjid dispute after the recent Allahabad High Court judgement announced on 30 September, 2010. However, in compliance of directions of Honâ<U+0080><U+0099>ble Supreme Court and the Honâ<U+0080><U+0099>ble Special Bench of Allahabad High Court at Lucknow, the Central Government is obliged to maintain the status-quo at Ram Janam Bhoomi-Babri Masjid Complex at Ayodhya, Uttar Pradesh for a period of 3 months from the date of pronouncement of the judgement by the Honâ<U+0080><U+0099>ble Special Bench of Allahabad High Court at Lucknow i.e. upto 30.12.2010. Union of India was not a party to any of the title suits.

question_title: DECLINE OF PARSI POPULATION
question_description: (a) whether the Ministry is aware that population growth of Parsi community is declining year by year; (b) if so, what fruitful action is taken by the Ministry in this regard; (c) whether the Ministry would consider any proposal from the Gujarat Government seeking funds for development of religious place Udwada of Parsi community; and (d) whether the Ministry would communicate with the State Government in this regard?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) IN THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) and (b): As per the decennial census reports, the population of Parsi community has declined from 111,791 in 1951 to 76,382 in 1991 and then to 69,601 in 2001. A scheme for control of decline of population of small minority community had been prepared. However, the Planning Commission has not accorded `in principle` approval to the proposal. (c) and (d): The Ministry has no scheme for development of religious places.

question_title: EQUITY CONTRIBUTION TO NMDFC .
question_description: (a) whether certain States have not contributed towards the equity of National Minority Development and Finance Corporation (NMDFC); (b) if so, the reasons therefor along with the names of the States which have not contributed their share of equity; and (c) the steps taken by Government to persuade the non-paying States to contribute their share so that minority beneficiaries of these States are not deprived of availing loans from NMDFC?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) FOR THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) Yes Sir. (b) The States of Arunanchal Pradesh, Goa, Meghalaya, Sikkim and the Union Territories (UTs) of Andaman & Nicobar, Daman & Diu and Lakshadweep have not contributed to the equity capital of National Minorities Development and Finance Corporation (NMDFC). The Government of Lakshadweep has sought exemption from contribution to the equity capital of NMDFC as the entire Muslim population falls under tribal category and derives benefits from the schemes of the Ministry of Tribal Affairs. The other State Governments / UT administrations have not assigned any reasons for non- contributions to the equity capital of NMDFC. Further, the States / Union Territories of Assam, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Dadra and Nagar Haveli, Delhi, Gujarat, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu & Kashmir, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharastra, Manipur, Mizoram, Nagaland, Orissa, Puducherry, Punjab, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Tripura, Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand and West Bengal, have not contributed their full share of equity capital to NMDFC. (c) The Ministry of Minority Affairs has addressed Governments of States/UTs regarding contribution to the equity capital of NMDFC. The matter is also raised at various meetings convened by the Ministry of Minority Affairs with the State Government/UT officials.

question_title: BAD CONDITION OF ANCIENT TEMPLES IN ANDHRA PRADESH .
question_description: (a) whether a number of ancient temples are in bad condition in Andhra Pradesh specially Srikalahasti in Chittoor district; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has noted the request for renovation of collapsed ancient structure in Andhra Pradesh; (d) whether any team has been sent to Andhra Pradesh to get an update of old structure; and (e) if so, the details thereof?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF PLANNING, PARLIAMENTARY AFFAIRS, PERSONNEL, PUBLIC GRIEVANCES AND PENSIONS (SHRI V. NARAYANASAMY) (a)&(b) (c)to(e) The protected ancient temples of Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) in Andhra Pradesh (A.P.) are in a good state of preservation. The temple at Srikalahasti in Chittoor District is not a protected monument of Archaeological Survey of India and is being maintained by the Endowments Department of Government of Andhra Pradesh. No such request is received by the Archaeological Survey of India, and hence no team has been sent.

question_title: INDIAN ART FORMS ON UNESCO HERITAGE LIST .
question_description: (a) whether three Indian art forms are on United nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organizationâ<U+0080><U+0099>s heritage list; and (b) if so, the details thereof?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF PLANNING, PARLIAMENTARY AFFAIRS, PERSONNEL, PUBLIC GRIEVANCES AND PENSION (SHRI V. NARAYANASAMY) a) & (b) Yes, Sir. Three items from India have been inscribed in November, 2010, on UNESCOâ<U+0080><U+0099>s Representative List of Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH). These are: (i) Mudiyettu : ritual theatre and dance drama, Kerala; (ii) Chhau Dance; and (iii) Kalbelia : folk songs and dances, Rajasthan. The following items from India are also inscribed on the UNESCOâ<U+0080><U+0099>s Representative List of ICH: 1. Ramlila : the traditional performance of the Ramayana; 2. The tradition of Vedic chanting; 3. Kutiyattam, Sanskrit theatre; 4. Ramman: religious festival and ritual theatre of the Garhwal Himalayas, India and 5. Nowrouz.

question_title: STUDY ON KOYA TRIBES .
question_description: (a) whether any anthropological or ethnic study been done of the Koya tribals in the Godavari valley and its tributaries covering Andhra Pradesh, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Maharashtra. (b) whether there is a demand for such a study to identify and understand the common dialects and customs of the tribals in the area; (c) if so, whether such a study has been commissioned; and (d) by when it would be completed?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF TRIBAL AFFAIRS (DR. TUSHAR A. CHAUDHARY) (a) Yes Sir. Anthropological studies have been done by the Anthropological Survey of India under the Ministry of Culture and the Scheduled Castes & Scheduled Tribes Research-cum-Training Institute run by the Government of Orissa. A list of such studies is enclosed as Annexure. (b) No, Sir. (c) & (d) Does not arise. Annexure referred to in reply to part (a) of the Rajya Sabha Unstarred Quiestion No.3692 for 13.12.2010. As per the information received from the Anthropological Survey of India, Kolkata; the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes Research-cum-Training Institute, Bhubaneswar; Tribal Research and Development Institute Bhopal; Tribal Research and Training Institute, Pune; Tribal Research & Training Institute, Raipur and Tribal Welfare Department, Government of Andhra Pradesh, the following studies have been done on the Koya tribes: 1. Anthropological Survey of India has carried out People of India studies in Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, Andhra Pradesh and Maharashtra. The details are: Maharashtra (i) Bose, D.K. 2004 Racha Koya, edited by K.S. Singh, People of India Series Part II, Volume-XXX. Andhra Pradesh (ii) Sudhakar Babu, 2003 Koya Dora, edited by K.S. Singh People India Series Part II, Volume-XIII. (iii) S.S. Shastry, 2003 Koya/Konda Rajulu, edited by K.S. Singh People of India series Part II, Volume XIII. (iv) Mohan Rao, K, 2003 Racha Koya, edited by K.S. Singh People of India series Part II, Volume-XIII. (v) Prasad, D.V., 2010 â<U+0080><U+009C>Cultural Dynamics of Resource Management: An Ethnographic Analysis of Adaptive Strategies of Koya Doraâ<U+0080> (Serial Publications), in press. (vi) Murthy, A.S.N., 1991 â<U+0080><U+0093> Religion and Society: a study on Koyas, Discovery Publishing House â<U+0080><U+0093> New Delhi. (vii) Rajendra Prasad, M, 2006. The Koya of Rampa Agency: Socio Political matrix of Marginalisation, Andhra University, Visakhapatnam (Unpublished Ph.D. thesis) Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Orissa People of India Volume for these States are in press. 2. The Scheduled Castes & Scheduled Tribes Research-cum-Training Institute, Bhubaneswar, has carried out anthropological study on the Koya tribe and published twp monographs as given below: (i) Mohapatra, Ch. P.K. (1969-70) â<U+0080><U+0093> Handbook on Koya, Adivasi Vol.XI. No.4. TRB, Bhubaneswar. (ii) Ibid (1992-93) â<U+0080><U+0093> The Koya, THRTI, Bhubaneswar.

question_title: ENCOURAGEMENT FOR YOUTH FROM BORDER AREAS .
question_description: (a) whether there is any scheme to encourage and help patriotic youth from Kashmir and other sensitive border areas to inspire them with Indian ideals and culture; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether Government ever tried to help the border area youth from distant villages like Chushul (Ladakh) and Tawang (Arunachal Pradesh); and (d) if so, the details thereof?
answer: THE MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF YOUTH AFFAIRS & SPORTS (SHRI PRATIK PRAKASHBAPU PATIL) (a)&(b): Yes, Sir. Government has introduced J&K Cultural Youth Exchange Programme under which the youth from the State are taken to various parts of the country to interact with their counterparts, and to facilitate a two-way exchange of culture, friendship and brotherhood. A similar scheme namely North Eastern Bharat Parikrama Programme has also been introduced for North East youth under which youth from various parts of the North Eastern States are provided opportunities to visit places of social, economic, industrial, scientific, academic, historical, religious and tourist importance in different parts of the country. A special scheme for girls in Border Districts including that of J&K and North East is being implemented under which vocational training is imparted to the girls. At present the scheme is being implemented in 200 districts which enables self employment opportunities. (c)&(d): Government of India through Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan (NYKS) undertakes multifarious programmes/activities through a large network of Youth Clubs/Mahila Mandals and Volunteers for the welfare of youth including border area youth from distant villages like Chushul (Ladakh) and Tawang (Arunachal Pradesh). The programmes and activities include capacity building of Youth Club members, skill upgradation programme for Women, Work Camps, Sports Promotion Activities etc.

question_title: EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS IN MINORITY CONCENTRATION AREAS .
question_description: (a) whether it is a fact that the number of educational institutions in minority concentration districts in the country is not adequate; (b) if so, the details thereof and the reasons therefor; and (c) the steps being taken to open adequate number of educational institutions in those areas?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT (SMT. D. PURANDESWARI) (a) to (c) Establishing educational institutions in Minority Concentration Districts (MCDs) is a priority for the Government. 90 MCDs are included in the 374 districts with low gross enrolment ratio. To improve access, equity and quality of education in MCDs, government has been taking several steps. During the year 2010-11, 13650 primary schools are being constructed, out of which 4969 schools are in districts with substantial minority population. Out of 2573 Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalayas (KGBVs) which were sanctioned, 427 KGBVs are for rural and urban areas of educationally backward muslim minority concentration areas. In addition, 64 model degree colleges out of the 374 identified for higher educationally backward districts with lower than national Gross Enrolment Ratio, are in minority concentration districts. Similarly out of 57 minority concentration districts eligible for polytechnics 36 districts have already been covered under the Sub-Mission on polytechnics.

question_title: CONDITIONS OF SINGLE WOMEN .
question_description: (a) whether Government is aware of the difficult conditions of single women in the country; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether any scheme has been formulated or proposed to be formulated for protecting the interest of the single women like widows, working women and deserted women; and (d) if so, the details thereof?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE OF THE MINISTRY OF WOMEN AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT (SHRIMATI KRISHNA TIRATH) (a) to (d): To address their needs, Government implements several schemes/ programmes for the welfare of women including working women, widows, deserted women, which can also be availed by single women, such as :- (i) Swadhar and Short Stay Homes for relief and rehabilitation of women in difficult circumstances. (ii) Support for Training & Employment Programme (STEP) under which skill upgradation training is provided to assetless and below poverty line women. (iii) Scheme of Working Women Hostel under which assistance is provided for the construction/expansion of hostel building with the objective of providing safe accommodation to single working women who are unmarried, widowed, divorced or separated as well as to the married women whose husband or immediate family does not reside in the same area. (iv) Indira Gandhi National Widow Pension Scheme (IGNWPS) under which pension is provided to the widow in the age group of 40-64 years who is living below poverty line. (v) Integrated Programme for Older Persons under which financial assistance is given to voluntary organizations for running and maintenance of old age homes, mobile medical units etc. for the destitute senior citizens and for setting up of Multi Facility Care Centre for Older Widow Women to provide full time shelter, care, training in income generating activities, conduct of religious programmes, yoga etc. to older widows.

question_title: FUNDS FOR RUNNING DAY CARE CENTRES .
question_description: (a) whether the proposal for release of funds for running day care centres at Gulbarga, Raichur, Chamrajnagar, Belgaum and Bangaluru urban areas is pending with the Central Government; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether it is a fact that the grant for the years 2008-09 and 2009-10 is pending with the Central Government; (d) whether the State Government has requested for increasing the said scheme to five more districts like Koppal, Mandya, Bijapur, Chitradurga and Gadag; and (e) if so, the details thereof ?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE OF THE MINISTRY OF WOMEN AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT (SHRIMATI KRISHNA TIRATH) (a) to (c): Rajiv Gandhi National Creche Scheme for the Children of Working Mothers envisages implementation through Central Social Welfare Board and two national level NGOs, namely, Indian Council for Child Welfare and Bhartiya Adim Jati Sevak Sangh. Funds are released by Government of India in the Ministry of Women & Child Development to the implementing agencies. Of these agencies, Central Social Welfare Board releases funds to the State Social Welfare Boards for implementing the scheme. The details of the pending proposals, under the scheme, for the financial years 2006-07, 2007-08 and 2008-09, with the Karnataka State Social Welfare Board are annexed. No proposal for the release of funds for the year 2009-10 is pending. (d) No, Sir. (e) Question does not arise.

question_title: LEVEL OF FOOD PROCESSING .
question_description: (a) whether it is not a fact that the food processing level in India is lower than the other developing and developed countries of the world; (b) to what extent the Vision 2015 Document helps in increasing the level of food processing in India and promotes industrial growth in the food processing sector; and (c) to what extent Government has been able to achieve to increase the perishable items from 6 per cent to 20 per cent, value addition from 20 per cent to 35 per cent and increase food trade from 1.5 per cent to 3 per cent since implementation of the Vision 2015 in 2005?
answer: THE MINISTER OF FOOD PROCESSING INDUSTRIES (SHRI SUBODH KANT SAHAI) (a): Yes, Sir. The food processing levels in India are lower than other developing and developed countries. (b) & (c): The Vision 2015 document had suggested a number of measures aimed at enhancing and stabilizing the income level of the farmers, providing choice to consumers in terms of greater variety and taste including traditional ethnic food, providing greater assurance about safety and quality of food to consumers, promoting a dynamic food processing industry, enhancing the competitiveness of food processing industry in both domestic as well as international markets, making the sector attractive for both domestic and foreign investors, achieving integration of the food processing infrastructure from farm to market, having a transparent and industry friendly regulatory regime and putting in place a transparent system of standards based on science. The Vision 2015 document also envisioned tripling the size of the processed food sector by increasing the level of processing of perishables from 6% to 20%, value addition from 20% to 35% and share in global food trade from 1.5% to 3% by 2015. As against this, it is estimated that currently, the processing levels have increased to about 11% with value addition estimated at 26%.

question_title: SETTING UP OF TIGER RESERVES .
question_description: (a) whether it is a fact that Government is considering to set up eight more tiger reserves in the country; (b) if so, the details thereof; (c) whether it is also a fact that Government is considering to bring out a tiger census report; and (d) if so, the details thereof?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) FOR ENVIRONMENT AND FORESTS (SHRI JAIRAM RAMESH) (a) & (b) The â<U+0080><U+009C>in-principleâ<U+0080> approval has been accorded by the National Tiger Conservation Authority for creation of four new tiger reserves, and the sites are: Biligiri Ranganatha Swamy Temple Sanctuary (Karnataka), Pilibhit (Uttar Pradesh), Ratapani (Madhya Pradesh) and Sunabeda (Orissa). Besides, the States have been advised to send proposals for declaring the following areas as Tiger Reserves: (i) Bor (Maharashtra) (ii) Suhelwa (Uttar Pradesh) (iii) Nagzira-Navegaon (Maharashtra) (iv) Satyamangalam (Tamil Nadu) (c) & (d) The country level tiger estimation using the refined methodology is done once in every four years for an assessment of the status of tiger, co-predators, prey animals and habitat. As per the findings of the all India Estimation of tiger using the refined methodology done in 2008, the total country-level population of tiger is 1411 (mid value); the lower and upper limits being 1165 and 1657 respectively. The recent assessment of tiger population is based on determining spatial occupancy of tigers throughout potential tiger forests and sampling such forests using camera traps in a statistical framework. This assessment is not comparable to the earlier total count using pugmarks owing to several shortcomings in the latter. The details of the last such assessment done in 2008 are at Annexure-I. Initiatives have been taken for the 2nd All India estimation of tigers using the above refined methodology.

question_title: ARREARS OF SIXTH PAY COMMISSION TO DOCTORS IN AMU .
question_description: (a) whether those Post â<U+0080><U+0093>Graduate Diploma/ degree holder doctors of Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College (J.N. M. C.) of A.M. U. who did not join service under that college after completing their three year course (2006-2009) have not been paid 60 per cent of their arrears which became due after their pay structure was revised after implementation of recommendations of the Sixth Central Pay Review Commission report, whereas those who joined service with the college after completing their tenure have been paid; and (b) if so, the reasons therefor and by when those left out are likely to get their arrears?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT (SMT.D.PURANDESWARI) (a) and (b) : According to the information furnished by the Aligarh Muslim University ,the payment of arrears has not been made to Junior Resident Doctors and Senior Resident Doctors, who have left the University, for want of certain clarifications. University has since informed that all such payment will be made by 31.12.2010.

question_title: PROMOTION OF STUDY OF SANSKRIT LANGUAGE AND VEDAS .
question_description: (a) the schemes of the Ministry for study and spread of Sanskrit language and Vedas; (b) whether any scheme is operational under the Ministry for preservation of Shrutis and Smrities and to train new generations in it; and (c) if so, the details of the annual budget thereof and the work and achievements made so far in this regard?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT (SMT. D. PURANDESWARI) (a) The Government is promoting and propagating Sanskrit Language through its three deemed Central Sanskrit Universities, viz. Rashtriya Sanskrit Sansthan (RSKS), New Delhi, Shri Lal Bahadur Shastri Rashtriya Sanskrit Vidyapeeth (SLBSRSV), New Delhi and Rashtriya Sanskrit Vidyapeeth (RSV), Tirupati. University Grants Commission is also providing development assistance to eligible Sanskrit Universities and Colleges and financial assistance to other Universities, which are having the Department of Sanskrit. Besides this, an autonomous body, Maharshi Sandipani Rashtriya Vedavidya Pratishthan (MSRVVP), Ujjain is also being provided financial assistance by this Ministry to promote learning of Vedas; (b) Shrutis are being promoted by MSRVVP, Ujjain under the schemes of (i) Financial Assistance to Vedic Institutions, and (ii) Financial Assistance to Teachers and Students under the Scheme for Preservation of Oral Tradition of Vedic Recitation and Smriti is a part of Dharma Shastra at Shastri (UG) and Acharya (PG) levels in the deemed Central Sanskrit Universities; and (c) During the year 2009-10, the annual budget of MSRVVP was Rs.8.00 crores; 52 Vedic institutions were provided financial assistance in which 3709 students were provided stipend.

question_title: WELFARE OF MUSLIMS
question_description: (a) whether Sachar Committee appointed for assessing the social, economic and educational status of Indian muslims, has revealed that their status is even worse than that of Schedule Tribes / Schedule Castes; (b) if so, the steps being taken by Government for the development of Muslims in view of the reports of Sachar Committee and Gopal Singh Committee; and (c) the action taken by Government in this regard?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) OF THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) to (c) : The Sachar Committee has observed on the basis of data of National Sample Survey Organization (NSSO) that Schedule Castes, Schedule Tribes and Muslims are the most disadvantaged communities. A number of steps have been taken by the Government to promote education among minorities including Muslims. The steps include, implementation of three scholarship schemes namely pre-matric, post-matric and merit-cum-means scholarship schemes for students belonging to minority communities. Besides, Maulana Azad National Fellowship Scheme for M.Phil. and Ph.D. students and Free Coaching & Allied Scheme have been implemented for minority students. Also, under Multi-sectoral Development Programme (MsDP), which is a special area development programme, approvals have been given for construction of 559 school buildings, 6679 additional class rooms, 37 hostels and 34 laboratories for primary, secondary, higher secondary / college education in 90 minority concentration districts (MCDs) where there is substantial minority population including Muslims. The follow-up action of the implementation of the recommendations of Sachar Committee is regularly reviewed on quarterly basis. The status in this regard is annexed. Lead banks have organized 313 entrepreneurial development programmes in blocks/districts/towns with substantial minority population. Under the Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya (KGBV) scheme, criteria of educationally backward blocks has been revised with effect from 1st April 2008 to cover blocks with less than 30% rural female literacy and in urban areas with less than national average of female literacy (53.67%: Census 2001). Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration (LBSNAA) has prepared a module for sensitization of organized civil services and it has been incorporated in their training programme. b. State Governments and Union Territory Administrations have been advised by Department of Personnel & Training for posting of Muslim police personnel in Thanas and Muslim health personnel and teachers in Muslim concentration areas. Revised guidelines on Communal Harmony have been issued. The Communal Violence (Prevention, Control and Rehabilitation of Victims) Bill, 2005 is under consideration of Parliament. (xii) Ministry of Panchayati Raj (up to 30th June, 2010): State Governments have been advised by Ministry of Panchayati Raj and Ministry of Urban Development to improve representation of minorities in local bodies. question_title: . MINORITY STATUS OF SIKHS IN J K
question_description: (a) whether it is a fact that Sikhs living in Jammu and Kashmir have not been kept under the category of minority community whereas Sikh community has been granted the status of minority community in the whole country; and (b) if so, the details thereof?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE), IN THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a)and (b): The declaration of minority communities namely Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Buddhists and Zoroastrians (Parsis), has been made under section 2(c) of National Commission for Minorities (NCM) Act,1992. As per Section 1(2) of the Act, it is applicable to whole of India except Jammu and Kashmir. However, since Sikhs are notified â<U+0080><U+0098>Minorityâ<U+0080><U+0099> under the Act, the benefits of the welfare schemes of the Ministry of Minority Affairs are being extended to eligible sections of Sikh community regardless of their place of stay within the country.

question_title: BER STATUS OF MARRIAGE BETWEEN M .NORS .
question_description: (a) Whether it is a lact that the Delhi High Court has recently declared marriage between two minors as valid; (b) if so, the details thereof; and (c) the reaction of Government with regard to this verdict and what action Government proposes to take thereon ?
answer: MINISTER OF LAW AND JUSTICE (DR. M. VEERAPPA MOILY) (a) to (c): A statement is laid on the Table of the House. Statement referred to in reply to parts (a), (b) and (c) of the Rajya Sabha Starred Question No.82 for answer on 15.11.2010. (a) & (b): The Hon`ble High Court of Delhi paragraphs 14 and 15 of its judgment and order dated 11 August, 2010 in Writ Petition (Criminal) 1003 of 2010 in the case of Jitender Kumar Sharma Vs. State and Another has inter alia observed as under:- `14. It is clear that because of the change in law brought .about by the enactment of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 and repeal of the Child Marriage Restraint Act, 1929, the statement of law with regard to the validity of a child marriage has to be modified. The legal principle that a marriage in` contravention of Clause (iii) of Section 5 of the HMA was `neither void nor voidable`, was established prior to the enactment of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006. The principle which is now applicable is that a marriage in contravention of Clause (iii) of Section 5 of the HMA is not ipso facto void but could be void if any of the circumstances enumerated in Section 12 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 is triggered and that, in any event, all such marriages would be voidable at the option of the `child` spouse in terms of Section 3 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006. 15. We also find that stronger punishments for offences under the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 have been prescribed and that the offences have also been made cognizable and non-bailable but, this does not in any event have any impact on the validity of`child marriage. This is apparent from the fact that while the legislature brought these changes on the punitive aspects of child marriages it, at the same time brought about conscious changes to the aspect having a bearing on the validity of child marriages. It made a specific provision for void marriages under certain circumstances but did not render all child marriages void. It also introduced the concept of a voidable child marriage. The flip-side of which clearly indicated that all child marriages were not void. For, one cannot make something voidable which is already void or invalid.`. (c): The extant position of law is that the marriage between two minors is not void but voidable at the option of the contracting party who was a child at the time of the marriage. The provisions of sections 5 (iii), 11, 13 (2) (iv) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 and sections 3 and 4 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 point towards this position of law. However, parties to such marriages are punishable in law as may be seen from the provisions of section 18 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 and sections 9, 10 and 11 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006. Hence, no action is considered necessary.

question_title: LEGISLATION TO BAN PERSONS GUILTY OF COMMUNAL VIOLENCE .
question_description: Whether Government would bring a comprehensive legislation to prevent participation in elections by persons found guilty in communal violence?
answer: MINISTER OF LAW AND JUSTICE (DR. M. VEERAPPA MOILY) Under clause (a) of sub-section (1) of section 8 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 a person convicted of an offence punishable under section 153A (offence of promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc., and doing acts prejudicial to maintenance of harmony) or sub-section (2) or sub-section (3) of section 505 (offence of making statement creating or promoting enmity, hatred or ill-will between classes or offence relating to such statement in any place of worship or in any assembly engaged in the performance of religious worship or religious ceremonies) of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860) shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of either House of Parliament or of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State, where the convicted person is sentenced to (i) only fine, for a period of six years from the date of such conviction; (ii) imprisonment, from the date of such conviction and shall continue to be disqualified for a further period of six years since his release. Hence no separate legislation is considered necessary.

question_title: COMPULSORY REGISTRATION OF MARRIAGES .
question_description: (a) whether Government is aware of the Supreme Court`s decisions that every marriage has to be compulsory registered; and (b) if so, by when Government would bring a Bill in this regard?
answer: MINISTER OF LAW AND JUSTICE (DR. M. VEERAPPA MOILY) (a) Yes Sir. The Hon`ble Supreme Court in its judgment dated 14.2.2006 in the case of Smt. Seema Vs Ashwani Kumar (AIR 2006 S.C. 1158) has directed that marriages of all persons who are citizens of India belonging to various religions should be made compulsorily registrable in their respective States. (b) As the subject matter falls under the concurrent list in the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution of India, information on the progress of implementation of the directions of the Hon`ble Supreme Court by various State Governments and Union territory Administrationi is being collected and studied As this will involve deep study and careful consideration it is not practicable to state any rigid time frame in this regard.

question_title: SCHEMES FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF SACHAR COMMITTEE REPORTS .
question_description: (a) whether Government has formulated any special schemes and allotted funds for the implementation of Sachar Committee report; and (b) if so, the details thereof?
answer: MINISTER OF STATE (INDEPENDENT CHARGE) OF THE MINISTRY OF MINORITY AFFAIRS (SALMAN KHURSHID) (a) and (b) : The Government has taken various decisions on the recommendations of the Sachar Committee and the follow-up action of the implementation of the recommendations is regularly reviewed on quarterly basis. The status in this regard is annexed. Government has formulated some special schemes for minorities such as Pre-matric Scholarship Scheme, Post-matric Scholarship Scheme, Merit-cum-Means Scholarship Scheme and Free Coaching & Allied Scheme and Multi-sectoral Development Programme (MsDP). Besides, the corpus of Maulana Azad Education Foundation (MAEF) and authorized share capital of the National Minorities Development & Finance Corporation (NMDFC) has been enhanced. All these are part of the decision taken on the follow up action on the recommendations of the Sachar Committee.
